title: Jorge Thomas
text:
Hello there
I‚Äôm Jorge and I like espresso made with light roast beans. I subscribe to Johnny Cash‚Äôs definition of paradise:
‚ÄÉ ‚Äì This morning, with her, having coffee.
Professionally I am an Electrical Engineer fond of sustainable energy sources; that means uncertainty, you know weather, and modelling. Somehow, I‚Äôve always manage to end up doing what I love the most: the development of data-driven algorithms either for providing business intelligence or supporting control systems.
I don‚Äôt bike but I live in Karlsruhe. If you want to know how I got into what today is Data Science click on the ‚ÄúAbout‚Äù tab. If you want to talk about data science, music or coffee instead, just drop me an email.
Have a nice day or evening.
J. Thomas

title: Projects
text:
Welcome to my portfolio of projects.
wip üöß
Here you‚Äôll find a mixture of professional, didactic and fun projects like Kaggle competetions an the like.The technologies I‚Äôve used are highlighted. Click on each project title for a detailed look!

title: Projects
text:
Machine Learning

Advanced regression techniques with visual analytics
In this classic Kaggle project you can follow my workflow where I‚Äôll give you some tips along the way, developing pipelines on the ETL phase of the DS cycle, as well as a tidy presentation on the EDA supported on visual analytics. Among the technologies I used are R with the state-of-the-art Tidyverse and Tidymodels packages. Quarto is the publishing system.

title: Projects
text:
Deep Learning
It is known that the most common type of dataset found in the industry is the tabular one. In this regard ML‚Äôs non-parametric methods with ensembling via bagging or boosting are king.
However, for datasets with high signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) like image recognition and language translation, DL methods are the best.

title: Projects
text:
Data Visualisation

E2E Dashboards with Tableau
Click here to see the dashboards on the Tableau Public website.

title: Projects
text:
Machine Learning:

Hierarchical clustering of daily load profiles
In the modern world of sector-coupled utilities, i.e., gas, water, heat & power distribution, time-series always have a very strong daily seasonality. Sequential data of demand are a strong function of calendar factors like hour and day type. Based on a famous proceeding with more than fourty citations in patents, I developed this heriarchical clustering algorithm as a tool to identify the most relevant daily patterns, e.g., weekends, holidays, workdays and anomalous profiles.

title: Projects

Survival Analysis
My professional entry point to what at that time was Data Mining, specifically in the area of reliability and risk assessment of power systems.

title: Projects
text:
Interactive Dashboards

IoT-Dashboards for energy management with Tableau
I designed these IoT-Dashboards with monitoring and BI purposes using Tableau Desktop. I also developed the whole E2E pipeline using technolgies like InfluxDB, SQLite, Python and Tableau Bridge to keep the dashboards up to date on a half-hour basis. This was the final part of the project dynOpt-En.


E2E automated energy reports for smart buildings
In 2019 for the EffMon project, I developed a set of functions to comunicate with Fraunhofer‚Äôs FROST-Server, an Open Source implementation of the OGC SensorThings API. Using Markdown publishing technologies, as well as libraries like ggplot, I automatised the entire KPI calculations and visualisations for reporting and management of the entire energy demand of the Fraunhofer IOSB building in Karlsruhe, including district heating, hot water, cooling tower and power. Click above on the title to see a video of the results!

title: About
text: Data was not everywhere

title: Projects
text:
Supervised Learning

- Machine Learning:

Advanced regression techniques with visual analytics
In this classic Kaggle project you can follow my workflow where I‚Äôll give you some tips along the way, developing pipelines on the ETL phase of the DS cycle, as well as a tidy presentation on the EDA supported on visual analytics. Among the technologies I used are R with the state-of-the-art Tidyverse and Tidymodels packages. Quarto is the publishing system.


Forecasting heat demand in buildings
With today‚Äôs advances on remote sensing, optimal energy management can be performed in the cloud. This is the maxima of project dynOpt-En, where I developed the two-days-ahead forecasting module for the MPC optimiser. Training a Generalised Additive Model (GAM) and using the Dark Sky API, free at that time, I manage to retrieve the weather variables from Numeric Weather Prediction models (NWP) needed as features.



- Deep Learning:
It is known that the most common type of dataset found in the industry is the tabular one. In this regard ML‚Äôs non-parametric methods with ensembling via bagging or boosting are king. However, for big datasets with high signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) like image recognition and language translation, DL methods are unbeatable.

Water demand prediction with LSTMs for pumps control



- Survival Analysis:
My professional entry point to what at that time was Data Mining, specifically in the area of reliability and risk assessment of power systems.

title: Projects
text:
Unsupervised Learning
Discovering patterns in the feature space.
Very often we have to do some previous ML for the sake of ML. Yes, that means performing some auto-labelling or at least identifying some possible ones.

- Machine Learning:

Hierarchical clustering of daily load profiles
In the modern world of sector-coupled utilities, i.e., gas, water, heat & power distribution, time-series always have a very strong daily seasonality. Sequential data of demand are a strong function of calendar factors like hour and day type. Based on a famous proceeding with more than fourty citations in patents, I developed this heriarchical clustering algorithm as a tool to identify the most relevant daily patterns, e.g., weekends, holidays, workdays and anomalous load profiles.



- Deep Learning:
